reviewerName: 1337 "It'll either be night to treasure or a ...
reviewText: At first I was skeptical about watching it, but here I am rating it 5 stars. It has great acting performance, good special effects, lots of humor well mixed with action, interesting plot and all around entertaining story. Characters are likable and as much as I expected the film to be cheesy and somewhere on B- (mainly because of Christian Slater's appearance in the movie), I was dead wrong to judge it like that. He did great performance just like all other well and little known stars of the movie. I highly recommend this movie. Do not just take my word for it. Let me tell you one thing. I do not often like B movies and when I do, it is usually a very good B movie. Well, this is not a B-movie in my opinion. Maybe special effects weren't super realistic in all places, but I'd put this movie on the shelf with other Hollywood movies. It deserves better ratings. Please watch a trailer for the movie and I hope you will give it a shot and like it in the end.
summary: Disregard 1-3 star reviews and reviewers, please

The plot involves something that deep down many of us would enjoy doing.  Out of the last 10 movies we have watch through Amazon - this is #1.  Great acting, great action & loads of gun & explosions.  The characters are exceptionally well done.

reviewText: I have heard the picture described as a cross between the Expendables and City Slickers, which is a pretty good way of looking at it. Like the Expendables is assembles a half dozen or so of past their prime film stars and like City Slickers it has a few good laughs. The laughs here I suspect are unintentional and the cast is mostly pretend bad asses pretending to be bad asses. So, this is a sort of B-level affair, where the Expendables is a big dumb action movie, this is more of a small, dumb action movie. Still, it is not without it's merits.Centering around an "extreme vacation", where rich old guys are able to live out their combat fantasies, to test their manhood if you will, without ever actually putting themselves in any danger, or so is the theory. They include a Texas millionaire cowboy (James Cromwell), a British adventurer (Sean Bean), a video game designer (Dominic Monaghan), an African arms dealer nicknamed "the Grim Reaper" (Ving Rhames), and for the life of me I can't remember what in the hell the last guy did.They are under the supervision of two ex-special ops soldiers (Christian Slater and the diminutive Freddy Rodriguez). I'm not sure what there mission was supposed to be because everybody has ulterior motives for why they are their in the first place. Mainly, the whole endeavor is just a set up for mercenary style action let loose on an evil warlord using the old bags of money to finance the whole thing, I think. Yet, the rich old farts seem in on a lot of it, evident by some of them seeking their own gain and agendas  including revenge and, of course, there is a traitor in their mitts.Timely entertainment if ever there was, as of right now on the NBC television network there is actually a reality show called "Stars Earn Stripes:, which is very similar in theory to this. A handful of over the hill celebrities, including Expendables co-star Terry Crews, act out military combat for our viewing pleasure. They also claim there non lethal combat fantasy as the real deal. This isn't arty enough to be imitating life and, of course, this isn't real life.All the rich guys have names that sound absurd including Dimidov, Grimaud (aka the Grim Reaper), Vanderbeer, and one of them is actually named Sin. This is the kind of stuff that used to play the Cineplex back in the 70's and 80's and even early 90's courteously of producers like Golan-Globus, to see it today is quite a surprise. Not that most people will see it at all, let alone in the multiplex. In fact, most of the world is getting this as a DVD premiere, but not us lucky Americans.The cast is full of familiar faces of days gone by, but many of them are just phoning this one in. Slater and Bean in particular are just going through the motions. Rhames has perfected his kind of bad ass tough guy persona to the point that I don't know if he knows how to act any other way. At least Cromwell rises to the occasion and has a good time with his over the top larger than life character. Likewise, Colm Meaney has fun chewing the scenery as the picture's main heavy even though this is the same part he played twenty years earlier in the superior Steven Seagal vehicle Under Siege. Monaghan, best known for his role as one of the hobbits in the Lord of the Rings trilogy, likewise enjoys himself in the movie's most overtly comical role.Directed by Maxim Korostysbevsky, I have no idea if that is his real name or not, I couldn't find out anything about him on the internet, I'm not even sure he's a real person. The violence is non graphic, nor bloody, the score fitfully rousing, the villains poorly defined and there are lots of slow mo running from fireballs. It all moves along pretty briskly at just over ninety minutes, and it looks pretty good for having been shot on a real low budget in Eastern Europe. Although thoroughly mediocre in everyway, I hate to admit it, but it is also kind of enjoyable.see my reviews at moviezonemagazine.com

reviewText: Here's The Lowedown on "Soldiers of Fortune" (An Action DVD review)...pretty good.Become a fan of "The Lowedown" on Facebook...Genre: 6.5 Movie: 4.5What's it about?Wealthy thrill-seekers pay huge premiums to have themselves inserted into military adventures, only this time things don't go exactly to plan.What did I think?I came into this not expecting anything but a low budget action movie...and that's pretty much what I got.  I did like the cast and the concept, but there were too many subplots that the movie didn't need..not everyone needs an ulterior motive here, guys.  If you are a Christian Slater fan (are there any left?) or will watch anything action...it's worth renting or buying for under $5.
summary: Worth a look for the right person.

reviewerName: The Movie Guy "Movies from A to Z"
reviewText: The film opens with Craig McCenzie (Christian Slater) leading a secret reconnaissance mission in Afghanistan. With the life of a fellow soldier (Freddy Rodríguez) in danger, Craig ignores orders to save him from our own CIA man Carter Mason (Colm Meaney). Rather than get a medal, they are dishonorably discharged from the service. They have fallen on hard times.Our heroes are then recruited by the lovely Cecelia (Oksana Korostyshevskaya) to lead a group of mercenaries to act as freedom fighter for a mineral wealthy island known as Snake Island (Black Sea?) against a ruthless colonel (Gennadi Vengerov) his equally ruthless daughter (Sarah Ann Schultz) and his arch enemy Carter Mason. However there is a catch to this whole thing. Not only must he free the island but do so while escorting 5 millionaires who want to "play soldier" for various reasons. They are funding the revolution. Thus a play on words of "Soldiers of Fortune."The 5 guys are:Dimidov (Sean Bean): He is originally from the island. He is in the mining business and already knows how to handle weapons.Grimaud aka Grim Reaper (Ving Rhames): An African general who knows how to fight. He sold the colonel weapons and he is late on his payment.Sin (Dominic Monaghan): Video game designer who makes violent video games. His psychologist recommended reality. For added measure he has a broken leg.Haussman (James Cromwell): He has done everything in life. His goal is to die so his kids get his fortune and not his wife (Ekaterina Suslova) known only as #5.Vanderbeer (Charlie Bewley): Runs a successful Wall Street hedge fund that made money when everyone lost. He just wants the bragging rights.Of course things don't go as planned and Christian Slater must save the day against overwhelming odds uncovering all kinds of schemes and plot twists. Unfortunately the plot remained as simple as a Steven Seagal movie. The film had potential but quickly falls off the edge. Slater being the main character was a stroke of bad casting as I don't see him convincing in this role.PARENTAL GUIDE; F-bomb, no sex, no nudity. 3 1/2 stars
Title: N/A

reviewText: "You and Ernesto are pimping out your revolution as some kind of tourist attraction for a bunch of millionaires and you expect me to be your guide." Iraq war vet Craig McCenzie (Slater) is living out his post war days in Montana playing poker and running a business out of his camper. He is recruited to become a "tour guide" to a group of millionaires who want to experience real warfare. What starts out as a "camp" soon takes a dangerous turn and a real battle takes place. I have to start by saying that even though the cast is very good and full of well known actors this is still a B movie. That said I actually enjoyed this. Normally not my kind of movie this one was entertaining enough to keep me watching and enjoying it. I didn't watch the trailer before viewing and when it got to the part where it revealed the plot point of being a reality-show type island I almost turned it off. The actors they picked to be the millionaires kept me watching and even though this is nothing but running around and shooting it is worth a watch. It also may have helped that I had no expectations about it going in. One of the better B movies that have come out it a while and Slater's best movie in a long time. Overall, an OK movie that is helped a lot by the casting. I surprisingly give it a B+.
summary: A bad made for TV movie that is made more legit by the casting. Surprisingly entertaining with great cast. I say B+

reviewText: With a silly story that does not make any sense, “Soldiers of Fortune” makes you feel like watching low-budget cult action flicks like James Glickenhaus’s “McBain” (starring Christopher Walken and Michael Ironside!), where things are so stupid that the film almost starts to feel like fun. Well, almost.The story of “Soldiers of Fortune” goes like this. Christian Slater plays Captain Craig McCenzie, a former US Special Forces soldier hired by a mysterious woman named Cecilia (Oxana Korostyshevskaya) to escort five thrill-seeking billionaires in their “military adventure.” The five super-rich men travel to a small island where evil Colonel Lupo (Gennadi Vengerov) rules with his evil daughter and Colm Meaney’s evil ex-CIA agent.The most impressive part of the film is its cast that includes Sean Bean, James Cromwell, Dominic Monaghan, Ving Rhames and Freddy Rodriguez. The players are all doing their best, but are sadly wasted.“Soldiers of Fortune” is a bad movie, but not bad enough to be qualified as “so-bad-it’s-good” film. At least “McBain” (which happens to share some plot elements) was not boring. Dull and slack “Soldiers of Fortune” is too weak to be called a guilty pleasure. As an orthodox action movie, everything about the film is just amateurish.
